Chapter 34: The TathÄgata's Ten Bodies and the Ocean of Marks
In explaining this chapter, it is divided into three parts:
First, explaining the reason for the chapter; second, explaining the Dharma-expounding host; third, explaining the meaning according to the text.

First, as for explaining the reason for the chapter, it clarifies that the previous chapter explains the Buddha's three karmas and two wisdoms entering the inconceivable state, pervasively vast and infinitely benefiting sentient beings. This chapter is about entering the body within the inconceivable wisdom through the three karmas, so this chapter comes.

Second, as for explaining the Dharma-expounding host, it clarifies that this ocean of marks is accomplished through the fruition of practice. Universal Worthy is practice, and it still causes the practitioner to explain his own fruition of the virtue of the fruition of practice.
Third, as for explaining the meaning according to the text, in this chapter of the sÅ«tra, it is divided into ninety-nine sections.

The first part, from At that time, Bodhisattva Samantabhadra to all the marks of the ocean, is one and a half lines of scripture, which is the initial general statement that the marks of the TathÄgata's body are as vast and numerous as the ocean.
The second briefly describes ninety-seven kinds of marks of a great man, divided into ninety-seven sections.
At the very end, it generally describes the marks as numerous as the dust motes in ten lotus treasury worlds, which is a general conclusion.

From At that time... below, there are a total of ninety-nine sections of scripture, which take the marks of the ocean of adornments as numerous as the dust motes in ten lotus treasury worlds as the main content, and are called the Chapter on the Ocean of Marks of the Ten Bodies.

The main idea of this chapter of the sÅ«tra is to clarify the three kinds of karmic activities, the vast and limitless body, speech, and wisdom, which benefit all sentient beings, and the auspicious marks born from the superior retribution of meritorious actions.

For example, at the beginning, it describes the thirty-two precious adornments on the top of the head, among which there is a mark of a great man called emitting light illuminating all directions, universally radiating immeasurable great nets of light.

Adorned with all kinds of wonderful treasures first clarifies the thirty-two kinds of treasures, which clarify the three kinds of karmic functions, which are the general characteristics of myriad virtues.

The two kinds of treasures are the two kinds of wisdom, which clarify that the Tathagata's three karmas and two wisdoms are the basis for cultivating myriad blessings, and therefore the ocean of the roots of myriad wholesome dharmas is none other than taking these three karmas and two wisdoms as its essence, which is why the initially manifested fruits are first listed as the foremost.
Moreover, they are used to adorn the head of the Tathagata.

The sutra says, Among them, there is a mark of a great being named 'illuminating all directions.'  The directions refer to the Dharma, which is the fundamental wisdom that accomplishes the Dharma of differentiating wisdom.

Radiating a vast network of immeasurable great lights refers to the karmic retribution of the wisdom of differentiation that establishes teachings according to faculties and saves all beings. From the perspective of the cause, it is called the network of light.
Adorned with all kinds of wonderful treasures means that all karmic fruits and meritorious marks obtained through retribution are adorned with these two kinds of wisdom.
The precious hair covering everywhere indicates that with wisdom, one's activities pervade and cover all, and this is the karmic result.
The precious hair being soft and dense indicates the karmic result of being soft with compassion and benefiting beings according to their capacities.

Each emitting the light of maá¹‡i jewels, filling all boundless worlds, and manifesting the Buddha's body with perfect appearance and characteristics, indicates that the various discriminating wisdoms arising from fundamental wisdom give rise to pure and unstained discriminating practices, and the karmic result of maá¹‡i jewels manifests the Buddha's body.
This is because these two wisdoms are pure and unobstructed, and all karmic results are subsumed into the function of wisdom, so they are all the same as the body.
In this one among the three karmas, there are ten, and in the three karmas above, there are thirty,
and in the two wisdoms above, there are twenty. In total, there are thirty-two kinds of precious uses to adorn the crown hair. This includes the crown and the body.

Briefly mentioning ninety-seven kinds of major marks of a great man, it clarifies and approximately follows the two kinds of wisdom of true and conventional, purifies the three karmas, practices the seven factors of enlightenment, and perfects the ten pÄramitÄs, which can purify all the nine grades of afflictions in the three realms and become the function of wisdom. Because wisdom is pure, the resulting rewards are also pure. Because wisdom is unobstructed and free, the resulting rewards are also free.

The nine grades of afflictions are one in the desire realm, four in the form realm, and four in the formless realm, totaling eight in the two upper realms. Together with one in the desire realm, they form the nine grades.

Those who are able to awaken to them will use the two kinds of wisdom, the seven factors of enlightenment, and the ten pÄramitÄs to skillfully benefit themselves and others, perfect the practices of Samantabhadra, and fully manifest the ninety-seven marks as their rewards.

Because the ten pÄramitÄs skillfully give rise to the free function of being in the three realms, they perfect the ten pÄramitÄ practices on top of the nine grades of afflictions, forming the ninety kinds of major marks of a great man.
Because the seven factors of enlightenment clearly manifest the skillful means above, they become seven kinds of spiritual powers.

Using these seven factors of enlightenment and ten perfections to assist the path, skillful means and practices assist in manifesting the nine grades of afflictions to form the two knowledges of truth and conventionality, causing great compassion to be fulfilled.
Within each grade of afflictions, ten kinds of practices are accomplished, and ten kinds of marks are born as retribution.
The ninety are matched with the ten perfections, and the seven are matched with the seven factors of enlightenment.

As for the marks as numerous as the dust particles in the lotus treasury world, they match the two knowledges of truth and conventionality, the three karmas, and the practice of Samantabhadra, which is all-pervading and all-encompassing.
Question:
From which teaching are these matches taken?
Answer:
All the teachings in this sutra come from its own teaching; other sutras cannot correspond with this teaching.
What is its own teaching?
Answer:
Because Samantabhadra is the Buddha's own practice, he is made to speak of the marks obtained as retribution by his own practice.
The practices of Samantabhadra are inseparable from the two knowledges of truth and convention, the seven factors of enlightenment, and the ten perfections.
But by the name one knows the teaching, by the teaching one knows the practice, and by the practice one subdues afflictions.
When afflictions are gone and one's recompense is accomplished, one then knows that the arising of causes and effects is itself the teaching.

One cannot cite the causes, effects, and rewards obtained through the practices of the other provisional teachings of the Three Vehicles as examples of what is cultivated here. One should only follow the lights emitted and the names of the bodhisattvas and seats in the previous chapters, and by analogy one can understand their meaning.

The Buddha's practice of Samantabhadra is inseparable from the gate of compassion and wisdom accomplished within the afflictions of the three realms and nine grounds. The causes and effects of the recompense-born are still accomplished within the afflictions of the three realms and nine grades. One attains the superior wisdom and practices, the free actions that transcend the three realms, and obtains the superior karmic rewards that surpass the three realms.
By following this one can understand and clarify the Buddha's intention, which is precisely the teaching of the sutra.

The following characteristics take these three karmas, two wisdoms, seven factors of enlightenment, and ten perfections as their essence. Moreover, the seven factors of enlightenment and nine perfections together form one perfection of wisdom, and the perfection of wisdom is the fruition of Buddhahood.
The seven factors of enlightenment and nine perfections are practices, and the resultant reward is the ninety-seven kinds of physical marks of a great person.

The ten lotus flower treasury world dust number physical marks of a great person are the perfect completion of the wisdom of discrimination and great compassion in the ten directions of the world, attained as the reward of the practices of Samantabhadra.
These two explanations before and after are both applicable.

The following characteristics are based on the fundamental wisdom that gives rise to the function of great compassion, and are born as rewards according to the wisdom of discrimination, as the text itself clarifies.
As the sutra says, the nape of the neck is well-developed, it means the three lines on the neck are well-formed.
It is said that in the Western Regions there is a fruit called nape, which is red in color and has three lines, and this is used as a comparison.
The cloud of Sumeru treasury means the right upper tusk of the Tathagata's great man's mark, which is like the appearance of Mount Sumeru's height and distance with jewel flames.
Chapter 35: The Merit and Virtue of the Tathagata's Radiance of the Auspicious Marks. In explaining this chapter, four topics are established:
1. Explaining the chapter title, 2. Explaining the reason for the chapter, 3. Explaining the teacher of the teaching, 4. Explaining the text according to the meaning.
1. Why is it called the Merit and Virtue of the Radiance of the Auspicious Marks?

It clarifies that the previous chapter has already explained that the ocean of marks of the ten bodies has the adornments of the ocean of marks as numerous as the dust motes in the lotus treasury worlds. This chapter is about the merit and virtue of the naturelessness of the marks in the Buddha's body. Therefore, it is about the marks of a great man attained through practice and merit, and the wisdom and principle of the Dharma body that forms the radiance according to practice. Therefore, the chapter title is established.
The wondrous principle and wisdom of following practice to destroy afflictions are used to accomplish the appearance of light as retribution.

Second, explaining the reason for this chapter: it clarifies that the characteristics of great people in the previous chapter are based on the TathÄgata's practice giving rise to retribution, so Samantabhadra is made to speak. This is because Samantabhadra's practice is the practice of all buddhas.

This light of the minor marks is the light of the merit and virtue of the fundamental wisdom of the Dharma body without nature, without substance, and without characteristics, which can greatly benefit beings. It still illuminates those with conditions with formless, substanceless light. It is like the sound of the formless celestial drum expounding the Dharma to bring about liberation. Therefore, this chapter is necessary.
Although principle and practice are non-dual and are the same in essence, now, based on the distinction of giving rise to effects and benefiting beings, there cannot be no sequence.

Third, explaining the master of the teaching, it clarifies that the fruition of such wondrous principle is the meaning of guiding and connecting with the precious hand, which symbolizes using the wondrous wisdom of the Dharma body's nature-light to guide and connect all sentient beings, thus establishing this chapter.
Why does the Buddha himself expound this chapter?

It clarifies that within the Buddha's fruition there are two kinds of ignorance: the ignorance of the vastness of phenomena and the ignorance of the merits and virtues of the light of the excellent characteristics. These two dharmas are not within the reach of the wisdom of bodhisattvas, and are only clarified upon the completion of the Buddha's fruition.

The wisdom and principle of the Dharma body merely serve as the supportless essence of practice and the condition for penetrating false emotions. The characteristics of merits and virtues that are aroused within the practice belong to Samantabhadra's accomplished practice.
Then, the rewards born from Samantabhadra's own practice are still caused by Samantabhadra himself to expound the fruition of the completion of his own practice.

The Asá¹ƒkhyeyakalpa chapter extensively explains the Dharma of counting. The Following Good Light Merit Chapter is the merit of the self-nature and non-reliance of the Dharma body and wisdom body. These two Dharmas are both not attained by relying on practice, because they are not reached by the practice of Samantabhadra, but only because they serve as the basis for practice. They are the Dharma of the final stage of the Buddha fruit when the practice of Samantabhadra is fulfilled. Therefore, the TathÄgata himself explains, clarifying the Dharma gates of his own stage to be explained by himself in the future stage, so as to prevent confusion for later learners.

This chapter explains the Dharma of benefiting beings that exists within the merit of the principle of formlessness of the Dharma body and wisdom body. It is still announced by the sound of the formless light celestial drum. It still explains the wondrous principle of formlessness of the Dharma body, suddenly ascending to the stage of the tenth ground and the merit of leaving defilements. Therefore,
it is not attained by the characteristics of the great vows, wisdom, compassion, and myriad practices of other lower stages. This is because it is the self-explanation of the TathÄgata's own stage.

Although the fruition of practice and the fruition of wisdom are not different, yet in terms of the Dharma, the stages are clearly distinguished, so that those who give rise to the mind and practice will not be confused in their understanding and practice.
The meaning is to clarify that the Dharma body and fundamental wisdom do not belong to what is cultivated and produced by practice, but only the great compassion and discriminating wisdom.
One must rely on this fundamental wisdom, add the power of Samantabhadra's great vows and aspirations, and cultivate and study with the fundamental wisdom as the unconditioned essence.

This Dharma body and fundamental wisdom, although adding the ten perfections, thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, four means of conversion, and four immeasurables to accomplish the practice of benefiting sentient beings, yet the fundamental wisdom and Dharma body are without self-nature that can be formed or destroyed, but can only serve as the essence of the uncontaminated, unconditioned, and unfettered fruits of all practices and vows in the three realms.

Because this chapter clarifies that the merit of this adornment can follow the function of practice without losing its own fruit, and extensively benefits sentient beings. This is the eternal Buddha fruit of all bodhisattva practices, therefore, the Thus-Come One himself explains it.
If there is no this fruition of wisdom and virtue, all practices will be impermanent.
Like the essence of space, it completely serves as the entire body for all sentient beings, yet space does not belong to cultivated birth.
As for following the text to explain the meaning, this section is divided into thirteen parts.
The first part, from At that time the World-Honored One to and became his retinue, has three lines of text, clarifying the part on the essence and function of the light.

The second part, from Buddha's disciple to after their lives ended, they were reborn in this heaven, has eight lines of text, clarifying when the Thus-Come One was born in the Tuá¹£ita Heaven, he emitted the wondrous principle of the Dharma body's pure light without action, the hells gained benefits, and the heavenly drum announced the cause.

The third section, from The Buddha's disciple, the bodhisattva's feet have a thousand-spoked wheel... to enters the samÄdhi of the seal of non-dependent cognition, has forty-two and a half lines of text, clarifying the sentient beings in the evil paths who are illuminated by the light, abandon their bodies and are reborn in the heavens, and the heavenly drum expounds the Dharma.

The fourth section, from At that time, the celestial sons hear this sound... to but cannot see, has four and a half lines of text, clarifying the celestial sons making offerings and going to the heavenly palace, but not being able to see Bodhisattva MahÄvairocana.

The fifth section, from At that time, there was a celestial son... to in the womb of Queen MÄyÄ, has about two lines of text, clarifying the celestial son informing the celestial assembly that the bodhisattva will be born in the human realm.

The sixth section, from At that time, the celestial sons observed with their heavenly eyes to repenting and removing all karmic hindrances and evil offenses, has fourteen and a half lines of text, clarifying that the celestial sons wish to go to the human realm to make offerings, and the sound of the celestial drum announces that Bodhisattva Vairocana has no coming or going, and also encourages the development of the bodhi mind and the repentance of offenses and evil.

The seventh section, from At that time, the celestial sons to all offenses and evil are completely purified, has twenty-seven and a half lines of text, clarifying the celestial drum's explanation for the celestial sons of the bodhisattvas' repentance of offenses and evil and the realization that karma is unborn.

The eighth section, from When this Dharma was spoken to still not manifesting even a small portion of the power of the VimalÄ samÄdhi, has eleven and a half lines of text, clarifying the celestial sons and celestial maidens' attainment of benefits.

The ninth section, from At that time, those celestial sons to the wholesome roots of one Ganges river's worth of sand, has twelve lines of text, clarifying the celestial sons setting up incense and flower offerings, and sentient beings who smell the incense having their eighty-four thousand afflictions all purified, accomplishing the wholesome roots of the sovereignty of the light of the cloud banner of incense.
If there are sentient beings who see its canopy, they plant the wholesome roots of a golden net turning-wheel king's one Ganges river's worth of sand.

The tenth section, from Buddha's disciple, bodhisattvas dwelling in this turning-wheel king's position to teaching and transforming sentient beings, has one and a half lines of text, clarifying the section on the vastness and narrowness of the realm and position of the golden net turning-wheel king's conversion.

The eleventh section, from Buddha's disciple, it is like the world of the bright mirror to will definitely be able to be reborn in that Buddha's land, has four lines of text, clarifying the section on citing the analogy of the TathÄgata Moon Wisdom, hearing the name and gaining benefits.

The twelfth section, from The Bodhisattva abiding... to accomplishing such a pure physical eye, has nine lines of text, clarifying that if there are those who encounter the light of this Golden Net Universal Monarch, they will immediately attain the Dharma door of the ten grounds.

The thirteenth section, from Buddha's disciple, if there is a person... to not yet, has twenty-one lines of text, clarifying the vast realm seen by the physical eye of this pure Golden Net Universal Monarch, which is difficult to measure.
As for explaining the text, in this chapter there are thirteen sections of text, which are divided into three parts:

First, the causes and conditions of the light, where it comes from; second, the causes and conditions of those touched by the light; third, the causes and conditions of the heavenly drum's ability to expound the Dharma.

The first explanation is of the cause of the light and where it comes from. It comes from the TathÄgata's own essence, the intrinsically pure Dharma body, the fundamental non-abiding wisdom, the intrinsically pure merit and virtue, which gives rise to the ability to accomplish the major and minor marks without relying on anything. Therefore, it is called the Chapter on the Merits and Virtues of the Light of the Minor Marks.

This light is equally possessed by all sentient beings. If it is not assisted and revealed by the practices and vows of Samantabhadra, it does not manifest. The essence of this light also cannot accomplish the unlimited great functions of the Dharma realm. Therefore, this sÅ«tra is called the SÅ«tra on the Mutual Adornment of Enlightenment and Practice.
When these two practices are perfected, they each reveal their own merits.
In the previous chapter, the major marks of a great person are accomplished through the practices of Samantabhadra, and so Samantabhadra is made to explain them.

In this chapter, the light of the minor marks and radiance is the Buddha's own fruition, the fundamentally non-abiding wisdom light of the unconditioned Dharma body, and so the Buddha himself explains it.
However, based on the teacher of the teaching to grasp the meaning of the sÅ«tra, among the lights, the light of the minor marks is immeasurable.
Now, based on this chapter, I will briefly mention three.

First, it mentions that the TathÄgata, the Worthy of Offerings, the Perfectly Enlightened One, has a minor mark named the King of Perfection, generally stating that fundamental wisdom is without support and without nature, yet is able to universally illuminate and is called the King of Perfection.
Specifically mentioning the use of this light, it says that from this minor mark emerges a great light called Fierce, which clarifies that this use is able to destroy delusion.
With 700,000 asaá¹ƒkhyeya lights as its retinue, this clarifies that this use is equipped with faculties.
The number 700 is based on the seven factors of enlightenment and the cessation of the suffering of the six paths.
It is called 700 because the number is long, all causing the arising of the ten grounds within the One Vehicle.
This is because the essence of this light is the light of the Buddha's fruition, and those reached by the light all rely on the basis.
Moreover, it is based on the seven grounds and below, which have practice and development, as 700.
Myriad refers to myriad practices.
Asamkhyeya clarifies that the light's essence is complete and pervades everywhere.

Next, it mentions when the Bodhisattva was in Tuá¹£ita Heaven, he emitted a great light called Banner King, illuminating worlds as numerous as the dust particles in ten Buddha lands. The sentient beings in the hells had their sufferings cease and attained the ten kinds of purity of eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind. They abandoned their hellish bodies and were reborn in Tuá¹£ita Heaven. Hearing the sound of the celestial drum expounding the Dharma, they attained the stainless samÄdhi and gave rise to the ten grounds.

This clarifies that the light illuminates the past causes. The minds of the ten faiths and understandings cultivated by the power of practice are not firm. There are those who give rise to evil paths due to negligence. When they encounter the light, their sufferings cease and their three karmas return to their original state.
This clarifies the three lives forming the fruition.
In the first life, they cultivate the minds of the ten faiths and understandings, but their minds are not focused and they commit evil deeds;
In the second life, they are reborn in the evil paths and dwell in the hells;

In the third life, they are illuminated by the light, their sufferings cease, they are reborn in Tuá¹£ita Heaven, and the resounding sound of the celestial drum proclaims the Dharma, accomplishing the fruition of the ten grounds.
This is the third life.

If one relies on wisdom to give rise to the mind in this teaching, solely seeks without slacking, cultivates skillful means with an undistracted mind, enters the Buddha's wisdom, and is born in the TathÄgata's family as the true child of the Buddha, then one is called a realized Buddha.

It is like the eldest son born to the chief consort of a wheel-turning king who possesses the marks of a wheel-turning king. Although he has not yet ascended to the position, he is the true seed of the king and is essentially no different.

In the same way, the bodhisattva who first gives rise to the mind in the ten abodes, newly gives rise to skillful means based on the seeds of faith, manifests his own correct wisdom, and is born in the TathÄgata's family.
Although he does not yet have the spiritual powers and abilities of a Buddha, he is in the position of a Buddha. However, his true wisdom-seed is no different from that of a Buddha.
From this one life onward, he cultivates and perfects his practices, and in accordance with his correct wisdom, enters the transformed birth, with spiritual powers and freedom.

It is like a person who cultivates the conditioned ten wholesome deeds with body, speech, and mind in one lifetime, and still attains rebirth in the heavens with the spiritual powers of a celestial being.

How much more so for one who is directly facing the wisdom of reality, whose Dharma body is in accord with the truth, who has no mind to do evil, and who is solely learning compassion - how could they not enter the transformed life body?

If we directly discuss it in terms of the ultimate truth, it extends to birth and death and is generally considered to be transformation. Realizing wisdom is Buddhahood, not based on spiritual powers. Spiritual powers are expedient means for benefiting sentient beings.
If we directly grasp the meaning of enlightenment, wisdom is right enlightenment. The rest, such as spiritual powers, descending to be born and becoming a Buddha, are all included in practice.
Now, in this chapter, it clarifies the perfect completion of enlightenment and practice. The Buddha clarifies the two kinds of light mentioned earlier.
The first is called King of Light Banner. It is based on the fundamental wisdom of the Dharma body of Buddhahood, clarifying the great function of breaking through delusions.
All cultivation of the Way, if it does not accord with this fundamental wisdom light, has no hope of becoming a Buddha.

The second is the light of the thousand-spoked wheel under the foot, called King of Perfect Completion. It clarifies the light of the bodhisattva's progress and added practices as the foot, symbolizing the practices that are carried out.
Constantly emitting forty kinds of light refers to the four stages before the ten grounds: the ten faiths, ten abodes, ten practices, and ten dedications.

Among them, there is one light that follows the various desires and pleasures of the six destinies and causes them all to be accomplished. Even those in AvÄ«ci Hell who experience uninterrupted suffering, upon encountering this light, are all reborn in Tuá¹£ita Heaven. The heavenly drum's resonant sound expounds the Dharma, and through repentance and removal of afflictions, one attains the samÄdhi of being free from defilements or the samÄdhi of the seal of non-reliance.

This one light is the light that arises in accordance with the capacities of all the six destinies to give rise to faith. The other three are the lights of the ten abodes, ten practices, and ten dedications, which are the causes for perfecting the ten grounds.

Because the three sagely stages before the grounds are the culmination of the vows and practices of perfect compassion and wisdom, and the ten grounds merely perfect the merits of the ten dedications before the grounds, there are no separate stages. Therefore, only forty lights are emitted, not fifty.
The fruition of no-more-training belongs to the Buddha's own stage and is not subject to practice.
The light from the soles of the feet illustrates the stages of the ten faiths, ten abodes, ten practices, and ten dedications of vows and practices.
The ten grounds are based on the Dharma to accomplish merits and virtues, fulfilling the previous vows.

Third, raising the right hand, the light from a single mark manifests immeasurable sovereign spiritual powers, which illustrates the light of attraction, because the hand symbolizes the meaning of attraction.
This is secretly the same as the expedient means in all worlds and the three realms, not known by worldly gods, humans, or the Three Vehicles.
Here, just these three kinds of light are used to pervade all existences in the world, and the rest are numerous and not discussed.
Second, as for those touched by the light, what are the causes and conditions?ğŸ”½The meaning of the sutra is that it clarifies the existence of faith in past lives.
As the sutra says, You have closely attended many good and virtuous friends, which clarifies that there were once seeds of faithful mind in the past.

Although they create evil karma and are born in hell, they have the seeds of faith, and the light shines on their bodies, their suffering ceases, and the seeds remain, enabling them to immediately give rise to the intention to abandon the body and be reborn in the heavens.
If they had no seeds of faith from previous lives, even if the light shone on their bodies, they would not be aware or know it.

Third, as for how the heavenly drum is able to expound the Dharma, as the sutra says, It is only due to the power of Vairocana's samÄdhi and the majestic power of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ that the sound emerges.
Generally, one hears it through three conditions:

First, the power of Vairocana Bodhisattva's samÄdhi; second, within the samÄdhi of no inherent nature, there is mastery and wondrous wisdom without action; third, sentient beings have previously heard the seeds of this Dharma body of no inherent nature and great wisdom, and only then are they able to hear such wondrous sounds.

Removing delusion and attaining the Way, like the samÄdhi of being free from defilements, refers to the wondrous principle of no nature, whose essence is devoid of middle and extremes, like the nature of space. By nature it is free from defilements, endowed with infinite wisdom, knowledge, and insight, and has no self-attachment. It must be aroused through skillful means and samÄdhi in order to become clear, like Dharma Wisdom Bodhisattva entering the samÄdhi of immeasurable skillful means. It is also like Sudhana attaining the wisdom and light of all buddhas on Mount Marvelous Peak. All of this is because the initial mind of the ten abodes first begins to manifest.

By this chapter, it is complete without leaving the initial place. Therefore, it returns to the Hall of Universal Light to explain the ten faiths, these eleven chapters, the eleven grounds, and the gateway to the fruition of buddhahood. This meaning is expressed, not leaving a single thought, not separated by a single moment, and thus attaining fruition.

The samÄdhi of skillful means means to let the nature of non-action be vast and naturally settled, neither collecting nor grasping, letting the mind be at ease by itself, with myriad delusions naturally purified and the Way naturally manifesting. Only then can one let go and act without losing the principle.

However, it is only by means of Samantabhadra's vows and practices that one can accomplish the great function of compassion and wisdom, the gateway of the unconditioned Dharma realm's dependent origination, just like the five stages of practice above.
As the sÅ«tra says, In form, sound, smell, taste, and touch, there are five hundred afflictions within, and also five hundred afflictions without.

Those with a predominance of anger have twenty-one thousand, those with a predominance of greed have twenty-one thousand, those with a predominance of delusion have twenty-one thousand, and those with an equal division of the three have twenty-one thousand.
Altogether there are eighty-four thousand.
As form, sound, smell, taste, and touch each have the five aggregates, and the ten entanglements and afflictions are all dominated by the mental faculty.
Knowing that form, sound, smell, taste, and touch are external, while feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are internal.
Like the mind and its objects, internal and external conditions come together to give rise to the ten kinds of afflictions.
Form, sound, smell, taste, touch, feeling, perception, mental formations, consciousness, and the mind mutually interpenetrate, each with ten internal and external aspects.
In this way, each of the ten internal and external afflictions can give rise to the ten kinds of afflictions, totaling five hundred afflictions for each of the internal and external objects.

Due to the mutual support of the mind and its objects, internal and external, the five aggregates form the objects, and the objects give rise to the perceiving mind. Due to these internal and external objects and the perceiving mind, the ten kinds of afflictions arise incessantly, up to eighty-four thousand.
In this way, the ten kinds of afflictions are all based on the five aggregates.

Within each affliction there are one hundred, taking the five aggregates in the ten afflictions to form the ten afflictions. Within each aggregate there are one hundred, totaling five hundred within the five aggregates.
The five aggregates form the five sense objects, and there are five hundred in each sense object.
Taking the sense objects and aggregates as internal and external, there are one thousand in total. Distributed among the seven consciousnesses, there are seven thousand.
Dividing them into the three times, three times seven is twenty-one, which corresponds to twenty-one thousand.
Based on those who have much anger, greed, or delusion, and those with equal parts, each has twenty-one thousand, totaling eighty-four thousand.
The rest of the text is self-explanatory.

Among the ten defilements, each has internal and external five aggregates. The ten defilements intermingle to form one hundred. For each of the one hundred defilements, there are five aggregates, totaling five hundred.
Because the inner mind conditions the outer objects, intermingling as primary and secondary, the inner and outer each have five hundred, totaling one thousand.
Because the manas is the cause for the six consciousnesses to create karma, there are seven thousand afflictions, as explained above.
Three times seven is twenty-one, also corresponding to twenty-one thousand.
